comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: What you could get for a Shilling, back then...!!  ;)

comment.author: 12742105@N00
comment._content: "Do not disappoint us."  Yeah, guilt is a must!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: And in the background uncut, unwrapped bread with lovely golden crisp crust on top of bottles of Lemons Pure Sweets, Fox's Glacier Mints and lots of other goodies to rot the teeth!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: But can anyone tell me the product name in the foreground on the stripey box? ...tlets??
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: They look like jam tarts, so presumably they are called 'Tartlets'!!??

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Well done Abaraphobia that's exactly what they are!  I'm surprised and a wee bit disappointed that the bright sparks in NLI didn't know what they were! Tsk, Tsk!  You can see the outer edges and some of the red jam in the tartlets (if you use your imagination).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Well done! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia] And as for you, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] not my fault if that particular brand of confectionery was well BEFORE MY TIME...  :D
So, really, they were called Tartlets? Any idea who made them?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Ah....my eyes glaze over with nostalgia when I see that picture....

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: It was the 10th anniversary of the Marian Year. Also, it was in 1954 that Fr. Patrick Peyton introduced his Family Rosary Crusade to Ireland which had as its motto "the family that prays together stays together". Another motto of their's was "a world at prayer is a world at peace".

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] Nostalgia for the sweets, or the prayers?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] And thanks for the 10th Anniversary tip - hadn't thought of that...
